title-group.article-title: Some health effects of global warming

body.p: The world continues in the grip of the COVID-19 pandemic but it is hoped that a vaccine will be available within the next 12 months and that this particular global issue will then be partially or completely resolved in the not too distant future. However, there are wider and far more serious and pressing issues that threaten the world and our species (and indeed, many other species), one of which is global warming. During the unprecedent times of COVID-19, the enforced and voluntary restrictions to travel resulted in a global reduction in both air pollutants and greenhouse gases (GHGs) which are the pinnacle contributors of the ‘Anthropocene Epoch’ [[1], [2], [3]]. The rapid and careless exploitation the Earth's resources by mankind dating back to the Industrial Revolution of the 1800s led to a significant impact on the planet's ecosystem and climate [4]. Climate change rapidly become a prominent dilemma experienced across the globe, but the onset of COVID-19 pandemic tipped the scales back, releasing the grips of mankind on the environment and resulting in temporarily favourable climate outcomes. Nonetheless, this is a temporarily situation as when global economies return to previous norms after COVID-19 is dealt with, global warming will have to be tackled with urgency lest a tipping point is reached that leads a runaway increase in global temperatures [5]. This set of Best Practice Guidelines in Early Human Development will focus on some health issues particularly pertaining to global warming.

One of the papers will explore the link between global warming, air pollution and two of the most common and debilitating neurological conditions, stroke and neurodegenerative disorders. A link has been shown between accumulated levels of air pollutants (especially particulates), and the incidence of ischemic strokes and dementia and this will be amplified in Zammit et al. “Neurological disorders vis-à-vis global warming.”

Another, more general topic is that of heat stress induced by global warming, particularly in the elderly, in infants and in individuals with co-morbid cardiovascular and/or respiratory conditions. All of these may have impaired thermoregulation that may be affected by extreme cold or warmth, with increased mortality as discussed by Calleja-Agius et al. in “The effect of global warming on mortality”.

An equally general and little discussed topic is that of the footprint created on the surrounding environment by the increasing production of medications for human and veterinary use. One of the papers in this collection will outline the various measures that have been introduced to promote green manufacturing and practices. Sammut Bartolo et al. in their article “Pharmaceuticals and the environment” will also discuss the reduction of wastage both on the supply side and the patient side who may hoard unnecessarily and inefficiently.

Gestational diabetes (GDM) is explored by Pace et al. in this collection's article “Gestational diabetes and environmental temperature – from epidemiological evidence to physiological mechanisms” as there is a complex association between this condition and environmental temperature. Indeed, studies have shown a relationship between rising environmental temperatures and the risk of both GDM and impaired beta cell function including the seasonal trends with a higher prevalence in summer months.

Type 2 diabetes is also surveyed by means of a review article by Cuschieri et al. that indicates both direct and indirect links of this condition with climate change in “The interaction between diabetes and climate change – A review on the dual global phenomena”. It is noted that temperature changes may trigger a person's susceptibility to develop diabetes and also exacerbate the effects of extant diabetes.
It is hoped that this BPG collection with some unusual facets on the topic of climate change may provide interested readers with reading matter that lies outside the box.
